natural problem:
One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$
natural solution: The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and \<theta> :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = [-3 / 2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]"
and h2 : "P t = P s"
and h3 : "0 \<le> \<theta> \<and> \<theta> \<le> pi / 2"
and h4 : "cos \<theta> = dot_product (P t) (P s) / (norm (P t) * norm (P s))"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and \<theta> :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = [-3 / 2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]"
and h2 : "P t = P s"
and h3 : "0 \<le> \<theta> \<and> \<theta> \<le> pi / 2"
and h4 : "cos \<theta> = dot_product (P t) (P s) / (norm (P t) * norm (P s))"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If P(t) = [2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t] and P(s) = [-3/2 + s, 2s, -6 + 2s] are two vectors in three dimensions such that P(t) = P(s), and the angle between them is theta such that 0 ≤ theta ≤ π/2, find the cosine of the angle theta if it is given by the dot product of the two vectors divided by the product of their norms. The final answer is 19/21.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real vec"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = vector [-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. P t = P s"
and h3 : "let cos_theta = (\<lambda> t s. (vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]) \<bullet> (vector [-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]) / 
(norm (vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]) * norm (vector [-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]))) in (\<exists> t s. cos_theta t s < 0)"
shows  "cos_theta t s = 19 / 21"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real vec"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = vector [-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. P t = P s"
and h3 : "let cos_theta = (\<lambda> t s. (vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]) \<bullet> (vector [-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]) / 
(norm (vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]) * norm (vector [-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]))) in (\<exists> t s. cos_theta t s < 0)"
shows  "cos_theta t s = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Two position vectors P(t) and P(s) are given by P(t) = <2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t> and P(s) = <-3/2 + s, 2s, -6 + 2s> respectively. There exist certain values of t and s such that P(t) equals P(s). Also, there exist values of t and s such that the cosine of the angle between the two vectors is negative. Find the cosine of the angle between the two vectors for any value of t and s. The final answer is 19/21.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. line1 t = vector [2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. line2 s = vector [-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. line1 t = line2 s"
and h3 : "let theta = angle_between (line1 t) (line2 s) in cos theta = 19 / 21"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. line1 t = vector [2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. line2 s = vector [-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. line1 t = line2 s"
and h3 : "let theta = angle_between (line1 t) (line2 s) in cos theta = 19 / 21"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Given two lines in 3D space, line1 and line2, described by the parametric equations:

line1: (2 - 3t)i + (-5 - 2t)j + (1 - 6t)k
line2: (-3/2 + s)i + (2s)j + (-6 + 2s)k

there is a point of intersection between line1 and line2. Let theta be the angle between these lines at the point of intersection. If the cosine of this angle is 19/21, prove that cos(theta) = 19/21.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s theta :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P t = (\<lambda> x. [2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t])"
and h1 : "P s = (\<lambda> x. [-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s])"
and h2 : "t = s"
and h3 : "theta = arccos ((dot (P t) (P s)) / (norm (P t) * norm (P s)))"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s theta :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P t = (\<lambda> x. [2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t])"
and h1 : "P s = (\<lambda> x. [-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s])"
and h2 : "t = s"
and h3 : "theta = arccos ((dot (P t) (P s)) / (norm (P t) * norm (P s)))"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the cosine of the angle θ between the vectors P(t) = [2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t] and P(s) = [-3/2 + s, 2s, -6 + 2s] where t = s. The final answer is 19/21.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s theta :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. P t = P s"
and h3 : "theta = acos((\<Sum>i \<in> {0,1,2}. P t i * P s i) / (sqrt(\<Sum>i \<in> {0,1,2}. (P t i)^2) * sqrt(\<Sum>i \<in> {0,1,2}. (P s i)^2)))"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s theta :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. P t = P s"
and h3 : "theta = acos((\<Sum>i \<in> {0,1,2}. P t i * P s i) / (sqrt(\<Sum>i \<in> {0,1,2}. (P t i)^2) * sqrt(\<Sum>i \<in> {0,1,2}. (P s i)^2)))"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given two parameterized vectors P(t) = (2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t) and P(s) = (-3/2 + s, 2s, -6 + 2s), there exists a point where these vectors intersect. Let θ be the angle between these two vectors at the point of intersection. Calculate the cosine of this angle. The final answer is 19/21.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and L1 L2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real*real"
assumes h0 : "L1 t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "L2 s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. L1 t = L2 s"
and h3 : "\<forall> t s. \<exists> p. (L1 t = p \<and> L2 s = p) \<longrightarrow> ((cos \<theta>) = ((L1 t \<bullet> L2 s) / (norm (L1 t) * norm (L2 s))))"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and L1 L2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real*real"
assumes h0 : "L1 t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "L2 s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. L1 t = L2 s"
and h3 : "\<forall> t s. \<exists> p. (L1 t = p \<and> L2 s = p) \<longrightarrow> ((cos \<theta>) = ((L1 t \<bullet> L2 s) / (norm (L1 t) * norm (L2 s))))"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider two lines in 3-dimensional space. The first line, L1, passes through the point (2, -5, 1) and is parallel to the vector (-3, -2, -6). The second line, L2, passes through the point (-3/2, 0, -6) and is parallel to the vector (1, 2, 2). If these two lines intersect at some point, find the cosine of the angle θ between these two lines. The final answer is 19/21.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and L1 L2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. L1 t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. L2 s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. L1 t = L2 s"
and h3 : "\<forall> t s. cos (angle_between (L1 t) (L2 s)) = 19 / 21"
shows  "cos (angle_between (L1 t) (L2 s)) = 19 / 21"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and L1 L2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. L1 t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. L2 s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. L1 t = L2 s"
and h3 : "\<forall> t s. cos (angle_between (L1 t) (L2 s)) = 19 / 21"
shows  "cos (angle_between (L1 t) (L2 s)) = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given two lines in 3D space, Line 1 defined by the parametric equations (x, y, z) = (2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t) for all t, and Line 2 defined by the parametric equations (x, y, z) = (-3/2 + s, 2s, -6 + 2s) for all s. The lines intersect at some point (t, s). The cosine of the angle between the two lines at the point of intersection is 19/21. Confirm that the cosine of the angle between the two lines at their point of intersection is indeed 19/21.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and theta :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = (-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s)"
and h2 : "acute_angle (P t) (P s) = theta"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and theta :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. P t = (2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. P s = (-3/2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s)"
and h2 : "acute_angle (P t) (P s) = theta"
shows  "cos theta = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Suppose that we have two parametric vector functions defined as follows: $P(t) = (2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t)$ and $P(s) = (-\frac{3}{2} + s, 2s, -6 + 2s)$. If the acute angle between these two vectors is denoted by $\theta$, then find the value of $\cos(\theta)$. The final answer is $\frac{19}{21}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real*real" and P :: "real*real*real" and theta :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. line1 t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. line2 s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. P = line1 t = line2 s"
and h3 : "\<theta> is the acute angle formed by the two lines at P"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and line1 line2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real*real*real" and P :: "real*real*real" and theta :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. line1 t = (2 - 3*t, -5 - 2*t, 1 - 6*t)"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. line2 s = (-3/2 + s, 2*s, -6 + 2*s)"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. P = line1 t = line2 s"
and h3 : "\<theta> is the acute angle formed by the two lines at P"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are two lines defined by the parametric equations: $line1(t) = (2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t)$ and $line2(s) = (-3/2 + s, 2s, -6 + 2s)$. There exists a point P that lies on both lines. If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by these two lines at point P, then the cosine of $\theta$ is $19/21$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t s :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. f t = vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. g s = vector [-3 / 2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. f t = g s"
and h3 : "let P = the (f t = g s) in
          let v = f (t + 1) - P in
          let w = g (s + 1) - P in
          cos (angle v w) = 19 / 21"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 One line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} 2 - 3t \\ -5 - 2t \\ 1 - 6t \end{pmatrix}.\]Another line is parameterized by
\[\begin{pmatrix} -\frac{3}{2} + s \\ 2s \\ -6 + 2s \end{pmatrix}.\]The two lines intersect at $P.$  If $\theta$ is the acute angle formed by the two lines at $P,$ then find $\cos \theta.$ The final Answer is \frac{19}{21}
 ### Proof
 The direction vectors of the lines are $\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2  \\ -6 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}.$  The cosine of the angle between them is then \[\frac{\begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}}{\left\| \begin{pmatrix} -3 \\ -2 \\ -6 \end{pmatrix} \right\| \left\| \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \right\|} = \frac{-19}{7 \cdot 3} = -\frac{19}{21}.\]Since $\theta$ is acute, $\cos \theta = \boxed{\frac{19}{21}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes t s :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> t. f t = vector [2 - 3 * t, -5 - 2 * t, 1 - 6 * t]"
and h1 : "\<forall> s. g s = vector [-3 / 2 + s, 2 * s, -6 + 2 * s]"
and h2 : "\<exists> t s. f t = g s"
and h3 : "let P = the (f t = g s) in
          let v = f (t + 1) - P in
          let w = g (s + 1) - P in
          cos (angle v w) = 19 / 21"
shows  "cos \<theta> = 19 / 21"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Two vector functions are defined as follows: $f(t) = [2 - 3t, -5 - 2t, 1 - 6t]$ and $g(s) = [-\frac{3}{2} + s, 2s, -6 + 2s]$. There exist $t$ and $s$ such that $f(t) = g(s)$. Let $P$ be the vector where $f(t) = g(s)$, $v$ be the vector $f(t+1) - P$, and $w$ be the vector $g(s+1) - P$. Find a value of $\theta$ such that $\cos(\theta)$, where $\theta$ is the angle between vectors $v$ and $w$, equals $\frac{19}{21}$.
